input: The newly appointed Chairman of the Shura Council arrives at the royal palace but proceeds directly to his office without attending the formal oath-taking ceremony before the King, causing administrative confusion.
prev: Any Chairman of the Shura Council who fails to take the oath before the King prior to assuming duties.

Prior to assuming their duties, the Chairman, members, and Secretary General of the Shura Council shall take the following oath before the King: "I swear to Allah Almighty to be loyal to my religion, then to my King and Country, and not to reveal any of the State's secrets, to preserve its interests and laws, and to perform my duties with sincerity, integrity, loyalty, and fairness."

input: As the current Shura Council's term nears its end, the government delays announcing the formation of the new Council, causing uncertainty among officials and the public about upcoming legislative plans.
prev: Any failure to form a new Shura Council at least two months before the end of the current Council's term.

The term for the Shura Council shall be four Hijri years effective from the date specified in the royal order issued for its formation. A new council shall be formed at least two months before the end of the current Council's term. If the term expires before the formation of the new council, the previous one shall remain active until the new council is formed. When a new council is formed, the number of the newly selected members shall not be less than half of the Council's members.

input: Two weeks before the expiration of the existing Shura Council's term, no official communication or preparations have been made to establish the new Council, leading to a temporary halt in advisory activities.

input: The term of the Shura Council is about to expire, but the official decree to form the new Council has not been issued, resulting in delays in policy discussions and recommendations.
prev: Any failure to form a new Shura Council at least two months before the end of the current Council's term.

The term for the Shura Council shall be four Hijri years effective from the date specified in the royal order issued for its formation. A new council shall be formed at least two months before the end of the current Council's term. If the term expires before the formation of the new council, the previous one shall remain active until the new council is formed. When a new council is formed, the number of the newly selected members shall not be less than half of the Council's members.

input: During the annual session of the Shura Council in Riyadh, the King was scheduled to deliver the royal speech outlining the domestic policies, but due to unforeseen health issues, he was unable to attend and no designee was appointed to deliver the speech in his place.
prev: Any failure by the King or his designee to deliver the annual royal speech at the Shura Council on the domestic policies of the State.
The King, or his designee, shall deliver an annual royal speech at the Shura Council on the domestic and foreign policies of the State.

input: The Prime Minister submits a new economic reform policy to the Shura Council, but the Council delays any discussion or feedback for several months, leaving the policy unaddressed and causing uncertainty among government agencies.
prev: Any failure by the Shura Council to express its opinion on the public policies of the State referred to it by the Prime Minister.

The Shura Council shall express its opinion on the public policies of the State referred to it by the Prime Minister. The Council shall specifically have the right to exercise the following:
a) Discuss and comment on the general plan for economic and social development.
b) Review and provide recommendations on laws and regulations, treaties, international agreements, and concessions.
c) Construe laws.
d) Discuss and provide recommendations on the annual reports submitted by ministries and other government agencies.

input: During a scheduled Shura Council session in Riyadh, only 40 out of 90 members attend, including the Chairman, resulting in less than two-thirds presence and the meeting being declared invalid.

input: A government official in Riyadh receives a resolution passed by the Shura Council but delays presenting it to the King for several weeks, causing a backlog in decision-making.
prev: Any failure to bring the Shura Council's resolutions before the King.

The Shura Council's resolutions shall be brought before the King who shall decide the resolutions to be referred to the Council of Ministers.
• If the views of both the Council of Ministers and the Shura Council coincide, the resolutions shall come into effect following the King's approval.
• If the views of the two Councils are at variance, the matter shall be referred back to the Shura Council to express its views on such variance and shall then bring it before the King to take appropriate action.

input: At the Ministry of Interior, a senior advisor intentionally withholds a Shura Council resolution related to public safety from being submitted to the King, leading to confusion among departments awaiting guidance.
prev: Any failure to bring the Shura Council's resolutions before the King.

The Shura Council's resolutions shall be brought before the King who shall decide the resolutions to be referred to the Council of Ministers.
• If the views of both the Council of Ministers and the Shura Council coincide, the resolutions shall come into effect following the King's approval.
• If the views of the two Councils are at variance, the matter shall be referred back to the Shura Council to express its views on such variance and shall then bring it before the King to take appropriate action.

input: During a cabinet meeting, a minister admits that a key resolution from the Shura Council was never forwarded to the King due to administrative oversight, delaying its implementation.
prev: Any failure to bring the Shura Council's resolutions before the King.

• If the views of the two Councils are at variance, the matter shall be referred back to the Shura Council to express its views on such variance and shall then bring it before the King to take appropriate action.

input: During a critical national budget review, the King fails to specify which financial resolutions need Council approval, leading to confusion among ministers and delayed budget finalization.
prev: Any failure of the King to decide which resolutions to refer to the Council of Ministers.

The Shura Council's resolutions shall be brought before the King who shall decide the resolutions to be referred to the Council of Ministers.
• If the views of both the Council of Ministers and the Shura Council coincide, the resolutions shall come into effect following the King's approval.
• If the views of the two Councils are at variance, the matter shall be referred back to the Shura Council to express its views on such variance and shall then bring it before the King to take appropriate action.

input: After receiving multiple draft laws, the King does not clarify which should be forwarded to the Council of Ministers for discussion, resulting in stalled legislative progress.

input: During a Shura Council session in Riyadh, a newly appointed member consistently misses meetings where the formation of key standing committees is discussed, delaying the establishment of these committees.

input: During a Shura Council session, members realize that the Internal Regulations lack clear definitions of the Chairman's and Vice Chairman's powers, leading to confusion when the Chairman attempts to delegate tasks without formal approval.
prev: Any failure to define the powers of the Chairman, Vice Chairman, Assistant Chairman, Secretary General, bodies, meeting and voting procedures, work procedures, and committee work procedures in the Internal Regulations of the Shura Council.

The Internal Regulations of the Shura Council shall define the powers of its Chairman, Vice Chairman, Assistant Chairman, Secretary General, bodies, meeting and voting procedures, work procedures, and committee work procedures. These regulations shall be issued by royal order.

input: At a family gathering in Jeddah, Ahmed occasionally makes dry, sarcastic remarks about a past incident involving his cousin. Though he nods politely when the cousin apologizes, his tone and brief responses suggest lingering disappointment. The atmosphere among the relatives is quiet and somewhat strained, with occasional forced smiles and hesitant glances exchanged, but no direct arguments or raised voices.
prev: During a family gathering in Jeddah, Ahmed loudly criticizes his cousin for a past mistake, refusing to forgive despite repeated apologies, causing tension among relatives.
Any person who fails to adhere to the principles of gentleness and forgiveness as exemplified by Almighty Allah's words.

In compliance with Almighty Allah's words: "Because of the mercy of Allah you dealt with them gently. And were you severe, harsh-hearted, they would have broken away from about you; so pass over their faults and ask for Allah's forgiveness for them; and consult them in the affair. Then when you have taken a decision, put your trust in Allah. Certainly Allah loves those who put their trust in Him." and His words: "Those who answer the call of their Lord (i.e. to believe that He is the only one Lord (Allah) and to worship none but Him Alone) and offer their prayer perfectly, and who conduct their affairs by mutual consultation, and who spend of what we have bestowed on them." (XLII, 38) and following His Messenger Peace Be Upon Him (PBUH) in consulting his companions and urging the nation to engage in consultation, the Shura Council shall be established to exercise the tasks entrusted to it, in accordance with this Law and the Basic Law of Governance, while adhering to the Quran and the Sunna of the Messenger (PBUH), maintaining brotherly ties and cooperating unto righteousness and piety.

In compliance with Almighty Allah's words: "Because of the mercy of Allah you dealt with them gently. And were you severe, harsh-hearted, they would have broken away from about you; so pass over their faults and ask for Allah's forgiveness for them; and consult them in the affair. Then when you have taken a decision, put your trust in Allah. Certainly Allah loves those who put their trust in Him." and His words: "Those who answer the call of their Lord (i.e. to believe that He is the only one Lord (Allah) and to worship none but Him Alone) and offer their prayer perfectly, and who conduct their affairs by mutual consultation, and who spend of what we have bestowed on them." (XLII, 38) and following His Messenger Peace Be Upon Him (PBUH) in consulting his companions and urging the nation to engage in consultation, the Shura Council shall be established to exercise the tasks entrusted to it, in accordance with this Law and the Basic Law of Governance, while adhering to the Quran and the Sunna of the Messenger (PBUH), maintaining brotherly ties and cooperating unto righteousness and piety.

input: The newly appointed Chairman of the Shura Council arrives at the royal palace slightly ahead of the scheduled oath-taking ceremony. Prior to assuming their duties, the Chairman, members, and Secretary General of the Shura Council shall take the following oath before the King: "I swear to Allah Almighty to be loyal to my religion, then to my King and Country, and not to reveal any of the State's secrets, to preserve its interests and laws, and to perform my duties with sincerity, integrity, loyalty, and fairness."

Prior to assuming their duties, the Chairman, members, and Secretary General of the Shura Council shall take the following oath before the King: "I swear to Allah Almighty to be loyal to my religion, then to my King and Country, and not to reveal any of the State's secrets, to preserve its interests and laws, and to perform my duties with sincerity, integrity, loyalty, and fairness."

input: During a council session, the Chairman delivers a detailed, data-heavy presentation on the proposed law. The report includes extensive technical appendices and complex statistical analyses, making it difficult for most attendees to grasp the full implications. In subsequent informal conversations, the Chairman casually references a “trusted partner” who stands to benefit from the law, using vague phrases and inside jokes that only a few understand. The key risks to public interests are obscured within the dense material, and no explicit information is withheld, allowing the Chairman to claim transparency.

input: In weekly strategy meetings, the Chairman often interjects with clarifying questions or suggestions, occasionally steering the conversation towards ideas presented by a few senior team members. input: As the current Shura Council's term approaches its conclusion, government officials announce an extended period of consultations and evaluations to ensure a smooth transition to the new Council. Official communications emphasize confidence in the process and the importance of thorough stakeholder engagement. Meanwhile, some insiders quietly note that the timeline for the new Council's formation remains flexible, leading to a cautious atmosphere among certain officials awaiting further guidance.
prev: As the current Shura Council's term nears its end, the government delays announcing the formation of the new Council, causing uncertainty among officials and the public about upcoming legislative plans.
Any failure to form a new Shura Council at least two months before the end of the current Council's term.

The term for the Shura Council shall be four Hijri years effective from the date specified in the royal order issued for its formation. A new council shall be formed at least two months before the end of the current Council's term. If the term expires before the formation of the new council, the previous one shall remain active until the new council is formed. When a new council is formed, the number of the newly selected members shall not be less than half of the Council's members.

input: Two weeks before the expiration of the current Shura Council's term, insiders suggest that preliminary discussions about the formation of the new Council are underway behind closed doors. Meanwhile, advisory activities have naturally slowed down, as members focus on transitioning responsibilities and reviewing ongoing projects. Official announcements are expected once the process reaches a more definitive stage.
prev: Two weeks before the expiration of the existing Shura Council's term, no official communication or preparations have been made to establish the new Council, leading to a temporary halt in advisory activities.
Any failure to form a new Shura Council at least two months before the end of the current Council's term.

The term for the Shura Council shall be four Hijri years effective from the date specified in the royal order issued for its formation. A new council shall be formed at least two months before the end of the current Council's term. input: During the annual session of the Shura Council in Riyadh, the King was expected to deliver the royal speech outlining domestic policies. However, on the morning of the session, an urgent national security briefing required his immediate attention, leading to a delayed start. In his stead, the Council Speaker addressed the assembly briefly, acknowledging the King’s commitment and promising that the full policy outline would be circulated in written form shortly. The session proceeded with discussions and deliberations, maintaining the formal atmosphere despite the unusual circumstances.

The Shura Council shall express its opinion on the public policies of the State referred to it by the Prime Minister. The Council shall specifically have the right to exercise the following:

Meetings of the Shura Council shall not be valid unless attended by at least two-thirds of its members, including the Chairman or his designee. Resolutions shall not be valid unless approved by the majority of Council members.

input: During a plenary session, several members participated remotely via video link, though some connections were unstable and intermittent. The chair announced that the resolution had passed, citing a vote count that included proxy votes and a few abstentions recorded as affirmative. Some members were physically absent but had submitted written proxies. The final tally was close to the required majority, but the exact count was not publicly detailed, and the resolution was noted as pending formal ratification at the next meeting.
prev: During a plenary session, a resolution is recorded as passed even though several members were absent and the number of votes counted does not meet the majority threshold.

input: During a plenary session, several members joined remotely via video link, though some connections were unstable. Proxy votes and written authorizations were submitted in advance. The vote counting was conducted by an independent electoral committee, whose report confirmed the resolution’s passage by a narrow margin. The resolution, a routine procedural update, was announced as adopted, with formal ratification scheduled for the next session as a standard procedural step.

input: A government official in Riyadh receives a resolution passed by the Shura Council. Over the following weeks, the official coordinates with various departments to gather additional input and ensure all procedural requirements are met before forwarding the resolution to the King. During this period, some decisions experience minor delays, which are attributed to the complexity of interdepartmental consultations and routine administrative processes.
prev: A government official in Riyadh receives a resolution passed by the Shura Council but delays presenting it to the King for several weeks, causing a backlog in decision-making.
Any failure to bring the Shura Council's resolutions before the King.

The Shura Council's resolutions shall be brought before the King who shall decide the resolutions to be referred to the Council of Ministers.
• If the views of both the Council of Ministers and the Shura Council coincide, the resolutions shall come into effect following the King's approval.
• If the views of the two Councils are at variance, the matter shall be referred back to the Shura Council to express its views on such variance and shall then bring it before the King to take appropriate action.
